hints_html:
Where is \(\sin\theta - \cos\theta\) equal to zero? Where is it positive? Where is it negative?

Try using symmetry.

\(\left|\sin\theta-\cos\theta\right|\) is symmetric about \(\theta=\pi/4\).

question: 1 (f)
sols_html:
(The following solution does not take advantage of the symmetry about \(\theta=\pi/4\). Solution 2 does.)

The average value of \(\left|\sin\theta-\cos\theta\right|\) over the interval \(0\leq\theta\leq\pi/2\) is

\[\begin{aligned} f_{ave}=\frac{1}{\pi/2} \int_0^{\pi/2} \left|\sin\theta-\cos\theta\right|d\theta.\end{aligned}\]

In order to simplify the absolute value, we split the domain of integration into regions where \(\sin\theta-\cos\theta\) is positive and negative. Then

\[\begin{aligned} f_{ave}&=\frac{2}{\pi} \left(\int_0^{\pi/4} (\cos\theta - \sin\theta) d\theta +\int_{\pi/4}^{\pi/2}(\sin\theta - \cos\theta) d\theta\right)\\ &=\frac{2}{\pi} \left(\left[\sin\theta + \cos\theta\right]_0^{\pi/4} +\left[ -\cos\theta - \sin\theta\right]_{\pi/4}^{\pi/2} \right)\\ &=\frac{2}{\pi} \left( \frac{1}{\sqrt2} +\frac{1}{\sqrt2}-0-1 -0-1 +\frac{1}{\sqrt2} +\frac{1}{\sqrt2} \right)\\ &=\frac{2}{\pi} \left( \frac{4}{\sqrt2} -2 \right)\\ &=\frac{4}{\pi} \left( \sqrt2 -1 \right)\end{aligned}\]

(The following solution takes advantage of symmetry about \(\theta=\pi/4\).)
The average value of \(\left|\sin\theta-\cos\theta\right|\) over the interval \(0\leq\theta\leq\pi/2\) is

\[\begin{aligned} f_{ave}=\frac{1}{\pi/2} \int_0^{\pi/2} \left|\sin\theta-\cos\theta\right|d\theta.\end{aligned}\]

If we draw a picture of the integrand, we can see that it is symmetric about \(\theta=\pi/4\). Motivated by this symmetry, we make a change of variables \(\theta=\pi/4+x\).

\[\begin{aligned} f_{ave}=\frac{2}{\pi} \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \left|\sin(\pi/4+x)-\cos(\pi/4+x)\right|dx.\end{aligned}\]

Now, this integrand is symmetric about the origin since

\[\begin{aligned} \left|\sin(\pi/4+x)-\cos(\pi/4+x)\right|&=\left|\cos(\pi/2-(\pi/4+x))-\sin(\pi/2-(\pi/4+x))\right|\\ &=\left|\cos(\pi/4-x)-\sin(\pi/4-x)\right|\\ &=\left|\sin(\pi/4-x)-\cos(\pi/4-x)\right|.\end{aligned}\]

Hence,

\[\begin{aligned} f_{ave}=\frac{2}{\pi} \cdot 2 \int_0^{\pi/4} \left|\sin(\pi/4+x)-\cos(\pi/4+x)\right|dx.\end{aligned}\]

Since \(\sin(\pi/4+x)-\cos(\pi/4+x)\) is positive for \(0\leq x\leq\pi/4\),

\[\begin{aligned} f_{ave}&=\frac{4}{\pi} \int_0^{\pi/4} \left(\sin(\pi/4+x)-\cos(\pi/4+x)\right) dx\\ &=\frac{4}{\pi}\left[-\cos(\pi/4+x)-\sin(\pi/4+x)\right]_0^{\pi/4} \\ &=\frac{4}{\pi}\left(-\cos(\pi/2)-\sin(\pi/2)+\cos(\pi/4)+\sin(\pi/4)\right)\\ &=\frac{4}{\pi}\left(0-1+\frac{2}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\\ &=\frac{4}{\pi}\left(\sqrt{2}-1\right)\end{aligned}\]
